questions.question:
Which one of the following options is CORRECT given three positive integers x, y and z, and a predicate
\(P(x)=\neg (x=1)\wedge \forall y(\exists z(x=y*z))\Rightarrow (y=x)\vee (y=1)\)

(GATE CSE 2011)
options:
A.

P(x) being true means that x is a prime number

B.

P(x) being true means that x is a number other than 1

C.

P(x) is always true irrespective of the value of x

D.

P(x) being true means that x has exactly two factors other than 1 and x
questions.correct_answer:
A.

P(x) being true means that x is a prime number
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Suppose the predicate F(x,y,t) is used to represent the statement that person x can fool person y at time t. which one of the statements below expresses best the meaning of the formula \(\forall x \exists y \exists t(\neg F (x, y, t))\)?

(GATE CSE 2010)
options:
A.

Everyone can fool some person at some time

B.

No one can fool everyone all the time

C.

Everyone cannot fool some person all the time

D.

No one can fool some person at some time
questions.correct_answer:
B.

No one can fool everyone all the time
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the following well-formed formulae:
I. \( eg orall x(P(x))\)
II. \( eg \exists x(P(x))\)
III. \( eg \exists x( eg P(x))\)
IV. \(\exists x( eg P(x))\)
Which of the above are equivalent?

(GATE CSE 2009)

"Gold and silver ornaments are precious".

S(x): x is a silver ornament
P(x): x is precious

questions.question:
P and Q are two propositions. Which of the following logical expressions are equivalent?
I. \(P\vee \sim Q \)
II.\(\sim (\sim P \wedge Q) \)
III.\((P \wedge Q)\vee (P\wedge \sim Q)\vee (\sim P\wedge \sim Q) \)
IV. \((P\wedge Q)\vee \vee (P\wedge \sim Q)\vee (\sim P\wedge Q)\)

(GATE CSE 2008)
options:
D.

All of I, II III and IV
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let fsa and pda be two predicates such that fsa(x) means x is a finite state automaton, and pda(y) means that y is a pushdown automaton. Let equivalent be another predicate such that equivalent (a, b) means a and b are equivalent. Which of the following first order logic statements represents the following:
Each finite state automaton has an equivalent pushdown automaton

(GATE CSE 2008)
questions.explanation:
None of these.

questions.question:
Consider the following propositional statements:
\(P1:((A\wedge B)\rightarrow C)\equiv (A\rightarrow C)\wedge (B\rightarrow C)\)
\( P2:((A\vee B)\rightarrow C)\equiv (A\rightarrow C)\vee (B\rightarrow C) \)
Which one of the following is true?

(GATE CSE 2006)
options:
A.

P1 is a tautology, but not P2

B.

P2 is a tautology, but not P1

D.

Both P1 and P2 are not tautologies
questions.correct_answer:
D.

Both P1 and P2 are not tautologies
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let P(x) and Q(x) be arbitrary predicates. Which of the following statements is always TRUE?

(GATE IT 2005)
options:
C.

\(\left(\forall x\left(P\left(x\right) \right) \implies \forall x \left( Q\left(x\right)\right)\right) \implies \left(\forall x \left( P\left(x\right) \implies Q\left(x\right)\right)\right)\)

D.

\(\left(\forall x \left( P\left(x\right)\right) \Leftrightarrow \left(\forall x \left( Q\left(x\right)\right)\right) \right) \implies \left(\forall x \left (P\left(x\right) \Leftrightarrow Q\left(x\right)\right)\right)\)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow
